https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/17/garde: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. — David Rose was taking this reporter’s photo. Every 30 seconds, with a cracker-size plastic clip he wore on the placket of his short-sleeved blue plaid shirt.

The device is called the Narrative, a “life-logging” camera embedded with a GPS device so that all the photos it takes are marked by your location. And Mr. Rose, an instructor and researcher at the M.I.T. Media Lab, ground zero for such playthings (though this one was made by a company in Sweden), had been wearing the Narrative for weeks. He is fascinated by how the meta-data it captures — the thousands of photos taken each day — might be used.

“It’s being marketed as ‘Don’t miss a great picture,’ ” he said. “But I’m interested in how it monitors what I’m doing all day long. How often do I snack? How often do I check my cellphone when I’m with the kids? How social am I? Can we measure the smiles of my friends, not who they are, but an aggregate thing, meaning how much smiling happens?” (Mr. Rose said his wife won’t let him wear the Narrative at home. This reporter sympathized and tilted her chin skyward. In such situations, you have to think of the jawline.)

The diminutive camera is just one of many devices Mr. Rose calls “enchanted objects” — that is, ordinary items that can do extraordinary things: cutlery and condiments that monitor your eating habits, an umbrella that tells you when it’s going to rain, a trash can that orders food, a table that displays your Facebook photos. They are all part of the rapidly expanding universe of smart-house wares embodied by this decade’s buzz phrase, the Internet of Things, which describes programmable objects that can sense and capture information all by themselves (and even talk to one another) because they are embedded with tiny processors.

The computer has atomized, as Mr. Rose likes to say, and its functions can be distributed about our households like an army of miniature genies. Mr. Rose has strewed his own household, a large, airy apartment in Brookline, with so many enchanted objects that it resembles a contemporary version of the Burrow, the magical home of the Weasley family in the Harry Potter series, with talking pill bottles, a teleporting cabinet (open a door and it connects by Skype to Mr. Rose’s parents in Wisconsin) and glowing orbs nestled among the Design Within Reach furniture.

There’s even a kind of Weasley clock, except it’s a doorbell — a speaker, really, encased in an elegant wooden box and affixed to a wall in the front hall — that is programmed to chime a different tune when each member of the family is approaching (it has a range of one mile).

Mr. Rose, a boyish-looking 47-year-old serial entrepreneur who has invented more than a few magical things, including the talking umbrella, that doorbell and the Facebook table, is the author of “Enchanted Objects: Design, Human Desire and the Internet of Things,” out this week from Scribner. In it, he proposes that the most delightful, successful smart things mimic the qualities found in the magical tools of fantasy and folklore — Excalibur or Sting, the swords of Arthur and Frodo, say, or the talking mirror in “Snow White” — by doing one or two things really well or, as he puts it, by fulfilling “human drives with emotional engagement and élan.”

In the scrum of talking heads wrestling to gain control of the narrative behind the Internet of Things, Mr. Rose is an engaging, plain-spoken guide. Magic matters, he said: “If the definition of God is to explain things we don’t understand, then God gets smaller and smaller.”

The smartphone or tablet with its bland, dark screen and multitude of “tiny, inscrutable icons” leaves him cold. Convergence, the great technological design mantra of the oughts, is to Mr. Rose a dystopian horror. He wants to keep his keys, his musical instruments, his wallet and his pens, along with his hand tools, maps, cameras and books. He’d simply like to embed some of those things with special powers.

On a recent breezy Monday, Mr. Rose had returned from leading an enchanted-objects workshop at the Copenhagen Institute of Interaction Design with an English magician and industrial designer named Adrian Westaway. (Yes, Mr. Westaway is a real magician, a member of the Magic Circle, a century-old secret society.) Mr. Rose said they took their students to Ikea to choose housewares they’d like to enchant. One group made a set of curtains you could open by waving your arms. Another group, inspired, he said, by the Sorting Hat at Hogwarts, made a bench consisting of three modules on wheels that could read the online dating profiles of whoever was sitting on it; it would nudge those who might be compatible toward each other and grow the distance between those who weren’t.

Back home, Mr. Rose offered a tour of his own enchanted universe, with a first stop at M.I.T.’s ravishing Media Lab, designed by the architect Fumihiko Maki. Glass walls divide research groups with magical names like Mediated Matter, Design Fictions and Changing Places. This last group has been developing a solution for small-space living called CityHome, which Mr. Rose likes to think of as an enchanted housing system. A central hub (imagine a super Murphy bed, or a giant Swiss Army knife) holds “spaces on demand” — a dining table, a bed, a desk, a kitchen and a bathroom that you can call upon as needed — and unfolds into a 12-by-18-foot space.
Daniel Goodman, 23, one of the graduate students working on the project, said those dimensions — just over 200 square feet — made for “the absolute smallest space we could imagine living in.”

He continued: “It’s for someone like me and maybe a partner that doesn’t have the money to live in Beacon Hill. It’s not unreasonable to think of robotic furniture. And why not treat it like a cellphone? Open it up to the app designers, so you don’t have to go out and buy an alarm clock or a thermostat.”

Mr. Rose added: “If you think of the home as an app store, a lot could be developed. There’s behavioral stuff: Can you track my television habits and make sure I’m not watching too much World Cup, or could you download a fully subsidized life and pay no rent?”
As Mr. Goodman said mischievously, “Oops, your child is crying. But we will continue to play high-pitched noises until you click on this Nike logo.”
The really neat thing about the CityHome is how you command its robotic elements.
“You can speak to your home, like it’s Hal or Jarvis,” Mr. Goodman said. “Or use gesture. We call that Jedi mode.”

The technology is simple: motion sensors read your arm movements. Right arm up, on go the lights. You draw the bed or the dining table out with a beckoning motion. Mr. Goodman added the coup de grâce: “CityHome date mode,” he said. Down came the shades, the lights glowed purple and the Reverend Al Green began to sing.

Over in Tangible Media, Sean Follmer, 27, a Ph.D. student, demonstrated a future vision of mutable materials that can be altered remotely. One prototype, the Transform table, has a surface consisting of an array of plastic pins connected to linear actuators, like a grid of rods on pistons, that are programmed to move in various patterns and in response to gesture. It undulated as we waved our hands over it, like sea anemones rippling underwater.

Mr. Follmer said they had created the table to explore “emotional motifs” in furniture: “Can it tell you things and you respond? Can it track your activity level, and that of your family members? Cars do an amazing job of using form to convey emotion. Can you have an emotional connection to your furniture?”

There are those who would argue that strong emotions have long been aroused by design. That’s sort of the point. But consider the Jealous Toaster, Mr. Rose said, describing an enchanted object designed by a team led by Simone Rebaudengo, an Italian designer, that becomes agitated when it’s not used enough (its lever waggles anxiously) and is programmed to “compete” against other toasters. It even tweets.
To Mr. Rose, it’s provocative because it maps a sophisticated human emotion, anxiety, onto an inert, or dumb, object.

In his book, he poses the question: Do we want one machine “agent,” a Siri or a Jarvis, to organize our households, or do we want the equivalent of a mechanical “Downton Abbey”? “As the cost of robotic services and replicants goes down,” he writes, “this becomes a design and lifestyle question similar to, ‘How many pairs of shoes will I have or teapots will I collect?’ ” He’s not entirely kidding.

The promise of such tools, of course, is that they will act as mechanical deputies, running the systems in our homes, our cars and our cities in ever more efficient ways, so we don’t have to. The downside is that these deputies or agents will not just be working for us, but for companies (like Google, which just purchased Nest, the programmable smart thermostat) that may not have our best interests at heart.
This reporter is simply hoping for a smaller cable bill, and that all the devices that are currently smartening up her home won’t break or in any way need her attention.

But in a post-Snowden world, said Jamer Hunt, director of the transdisciplinary design program at Parsons the New School for Design, most people are looking “more closely at where their bits and bytes and electrons are ending up, and who owns that information.”

What Paola Antonelli, senior curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, finds enchanting, she said, is the access that processor-embedded objects give us — the connection to the Internet and other systems — rather than the objects themselves. “Of course, the other side of the medal is that the people from the infrastructures have access to us,” said Ms. Antonelli, whose 2011 show, “Talk to Me,” explored just this sort of communication between people and things. “That’s what happens when you upload yourself. It’s a blood transfusion.”

On the one hand, some shrug off the data-mining habits of big companies. “What do you think credit card companies have been doing for all these years?” said John Maeda, a computer scientist and designer who is now a partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield Byers, the venture capital firm that funded Nest, among other “smart thing” innovations. But many, including Dr. Maeda, think that at the very least we should be compensated for the information companies are profiting from.

Sherry Turkle, director of the M.I.T. Initiative on Technology and Self and the author, most recently, of “Alone Together, Why We Expect More from Technology and Less from Each Other,” said that she is unnerved by the legacy of “the regime of memory that we’ve set up,” as she described Google’s and other search engines’ policy of recording every search. “We didn’t get to vote on this regime, there’s no law, and we are told that there is no going back,” she said. “I don’t accept this. The new regime comes with an extravagant language of gifts and miracles and how our dreams will come true and companies will do no evil. Well, that’s the way people in fairy tales talk. But if you remember your fairy tales, there is always a cost.”

At his apartment, Mr. Rose demonstrated the enchantments of his oiled walnut furniture, a digital future encased in a handmade 19th-century skin: the Skype cabinet, which allows his son to talk to his grandparents; the Facebook table, which sips photographs from a smartphone left on top; the doorbell that announces the approach of family. In the bathroom, a talking pill bottle known as the GlowCap reminds Mr. Rose to take his blood-pressure medicine, orders a new prescription when he runs out and lets him know if his father, who also suffers from hypertension, is taking his meds. Social nudges and behavioral feedback loops are of particular interest to Mr. Rose as an inventor.

“This tremendous amount of data we’re all creating is not necessarily evil,” he said. “People shouldn’t assume that data is just shared by everyone in the world. I’m sharing data with my father because it’s important to both of us. In many cases, having this digital portrait of yourself is a really powerful tool for reflection and change.”

Still, can there be too many enchanted objects, a result of what Mr. Hunt described as “the fever dream of technologists,” that may ultimately be destined for Sky Mall, or the junk heap? “They’ll be the gift for the man who has everything,” Mr. Hunt said. “I’m not a Luddite, but there is a kind of boys-with-toys aspect to all this, a fantasy world that is appealing to a subset of our population, but perhaps not everybody.”

Dr. Maeda, who has been head of research at the Media Lab and president of the Rhode Island School of Design, offered a food analogy. “Paula Deen used to say, ‘Just add a stick of butter,’ ” he said. “And for a while it was, get that little microprocessor in there, and it’s like, ‘Yum, everything tastes better with microprocessors.’ We’ve been technologically led for a long time, but now we’re in a space of, ‘Hey, we’re regular people, maybe we’ll make just a few things smarter.’ My position on the Internet of Things is that if it’s plugged into a wall, it’s going to get more enchanted. You will always have people who will overshoot, who will put the stick of butter in everything, and God bless them. But regular people who are going to live a healthy home life in the future will have a combination of the smart things and, dare I say, the dumb things.”
Dr. Maeda loves his silverware, his balky windows and his door that “opens sometimes,” he said. “I don’t have to make out technologically with every device.”

Twelve years ago, Mr. Rose designed an alluring frosted glass sphere you could program to track any kind of data you chose (the weather, for example, or the pollen count), and it would glow in various colors and strengths. He called it the Ambient Orb, and it’s a nice example of what he describes as glanceable technology, a device that presents information in a way that you can read simply and quickly, with just a glance, without taking too much of your attention.

That’s the idea, anyway. When Mr. Rose first brought it home, the orb was trained to track his stock portfolio, until his wife began watching it to the point of obsession, as he writes in his book. (A psychotherapist, she has asked that her name not be used in print.) The orb, he quickly realized, was not always “a benign influence.”
The other day, it sat demurely on his desk. It was unlit, white and chaste as an egg. But if we cranked it up, what might Mr. Rose program it to track right now?
Mr. Rose answered without hesitation, “My Amazon ratings.”
https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/06/fashi: You needn’t Google far for recent case studies of Internet outrage. Log in to a social network and you’ll find it directed at celebrities and civilians alike. (See: Woody Allen, Stephen Colbert and Justine Sacco, the former communications director for IAC who posted an insensitive Twitter message about AIDS in Africa.) Politicians are a perennial favorite: Chris Christie, Rob Ford, Anthony Weiner. Then there’s the bigger game: courts of law, social movements, news media outlets, corporations and governments that have rubbed people the wrong way.
As a now-hackneyed joke goes on Twitter, “What are we angry about today?”

Bile has been a part of the Internet as long as Al Gore has; peruse any epithet-laced comments section or, worse, a chat room. But the last few years have seen it crawl from under the shadowy bridges patrolled by anonymous trolls and emerge into the sunshine of social media, where people proudly trumpet their ethical outrage.

A 2013 study, from Beihang University in Beijing, of Weibo, a Twitter-like site, found that anger is the emotion that spreads the most easily over social media. Joy came in a distant second. The main difference, said Ryan Martin, a psychology professor at the University of Wisconsin, Green Bay, who studies anger, is that although we tend to share the happiness only of people we are close to, we are willing to join in the rage of strangers. As the study suggests, outrage is lavishly rewarded on social media, whether through supportive comments, retweets or Facebook likes. People prone to Internet outrage are looking for validation, Professor Martin said. “They want to hear that others share it,” he said, “because they feel they’re vindicated and a little less lonely and isolated in their belief.”

Certainly, outrage can function as a corrective or anguished expression of helplessness, punishing the offending party if he, she or it has not been given any official penalty; think of George Zimmerman. Moreover, it can double as effective activism, forcing a response from the powers that be, as in the case of Ms. Sacco, whom IAC fired the day after her post went viral and who inspired someone to create a website with her name that redirects visitors to the nonprofit alliance Aid for Africa.
But Internet outrage often says more about the commenter than the cause, and its deployment may do more harm than good, to the instigator and the issue.

In another 2013 study, Professor Martin determined that people susceptible to Internet rage are also angrier than the general population, a finding that should come as little shock. “They expressed their anger less healthily, in maladaptive ways,” he said. “They would either yell and scream or suppress it, but very few had any adaptive coping strategies. People who rant online in any way tend to get into more physical and verbal altercations.”

Correlation is not causation; voicing outrage on the Internet may not lead to a fistfight when the laptop is closed. But while expressing anger led to short-term relaxation for the study’s participants, Professor Martin said that “previous research on catharsis shows that people who vent end up being angrier down the road.”

Yet outrage carries a different flavor from pure anger; it suggests an affront to one’s value system as opposed to seething, Hulk-like fury. So whereas a venomous insult from an anonymous commenter simply seeks to tear down another person or institution, an outraged Twitter post from an identified account calls attention to the user’s own probity. By throwing 140-character stones from our Google Glass houses, we preserve our belief (or delusion) that we are morally superior to those who have offended us.

The emotion plays well on social media because of its brevity and conviction, too. A 700-word Facebook post accounting for all sides of a contentious issue is unlikely to garner as many readers and endorsements as a one-sentence quip blaring heightened feelings.

One type of outrage is particularly appealing on social media: comedic anger. A bitingly clever takedown is sure to be circulated, though it is usually the same brand of hostility veiled in amusement. Unsurprisingly, some of the most popular outragers on social media are comedians, a professional class known for transforming wrath into wit and for neediness; Professor Martin pointed to Ricky Gervais as a skillful Twitter commingler of indignation and humor. His most popular posts attack religion and the hunting of animals; the one with the most retweets, by far, is this riff: “Same-sex marriage isn’t gay privilege, it’s equal rights. Privilege would be something like gay people not paying taxes. Like churches don’t.”

The outraged may also be enacting a defense mechanism reinforced by the very culture of Internet ire. When you’re personally upset by something, it’s difficult to be counterattacked for your ethical injury. To state one’s outrage is to insulate oneself from criticism in the acid bath of the web.

But such responses can overshadow or diminish the complexity of a subject, narrowing into a reductive meme or hashtag rather than opening up a thoughtful debate. Twitter response to Donald Sterling’s racist comments, #BoycottClippers, was heartening. But the furor over one octogenarian’s bigotry trumped the NBA’s longstanding toleration of his discriminatory business practices, not to mention an opportunity to spotlight the league’s exploitation of African-American youth for profit, as Theresa Runstedtler, an American University history professor, has argued. (Another wrinkle brought up by, among others, Bill Maher: that we get upset only when our own privacy is compromised, not that of others.)

Furthermore, outraged comments are sometimes more offensive than the originating misconduct. In response to Ms. Sacco, for instance, a number of Twitter users urged for her to be killed or raped and get AIDS herself. When Ruth Graham, a journalist, wrote a Slate article called “Against YA,” with a subheading suggesting “you should feel embarrassed when what you’re reading was written for children,” thousands of adult readers of young-adult fiction took to the comments section and Twitter to excoriate Ms. Graham with language that would fit right in with surly teenagers.

Mobs breed a sense of anonymity, and in the midst of trending Twitter outrage, Professor Martin said, “you may feel anonymous, even if you’re not really.” Such perceived anonymity encourages people — even seemingly sensitive readers of “The Fault in Our Stars” — to say things they likely would not in person.

Though we are quick to condemn callousness and prejudice as a form of bullying, we less readily interrogate our own participation, even as bystanders, in the widespread attack of a single person, which is a classic example of bullying. We may justify our reaction as appropriate remediation for whatever crime has been perpetrated, but fighting fire with fire rarely elevates the discourse.

Ultimately, Internet outrage is the milquetoast cousin to direct action, a way to protest by tapping and clicking rather than boycotting and marching. It is a noble endeavor to become incensed about a cause and risk arrest or toil without acclamation for one’s deeply held beliefs. Less honorable is joining a digital pile-on as a means of propping up one’s ego, even if it comes in the form of entertaining zings.
Perhaps the real problem, Professor Martin suggested, isn’t our rage but our rashness, and its relationship to our easily accessible devices.
“The Internet exacerbates impulse-control problems,” he said. “You get mad, and you can tell the world about it in moments before you’ve had a chance to calm down and think things through.”

https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/18/busin: WHAT defines native advertising, a trendy marketing term for paid content, is that it does not look like advertising because it adopts the appearance of online editorial content. Native advertising in article form — usually labeled advertisements, but still confusing to some readers — is common in publications like The Atlantic and The New Yorker, while on BuzzFeed such ads take the form of sponsored posts.
Now LinkedIn has a new twist on native advertising, with Mercedes-Benz using the professional networking website to promote its 2015 C-Class line.

On Thursday, the luxury car brand introduced a contest, “Driven to Perform,” in which a LinkedIn user will win a two-year lease of a Mercedes C300. Unlike typical giveaways, users will not enter the contest on their own behalf, but rather will nominate someone in their LinkedIn network. In the spirit of recommendations that users contribute to one another’s profiles, Mercedes is asking LinkedIn users to nominate colleagues by highlighting their professional accomplishments and attributes in short recommendations (500 characters or fewer), along with how, as stated in the contest’s rules, the nominee’s “personality qualities meet the sophistication of the Mercedes-Benz brand.”

The brand also will weigh how popular and active nominees are on social networks. The contest closes on Aug. 18, and the winner will be announced in September. The estimated value of the lease is $11,353, and the winner also will receive a check for $4,865 to help offset taxes.

The concept for the contest, and display ads promoting it on LinkedIn, are by Razorfish New York, part of the Publicis Groupe. Mercedes-Benz USA, which declined to reveal expenditures for the contest, spent a total of $323.1 million on advertising in 2014, $70.2 million of it to advertise the C-Class, according to the Kantar Media unit of WPP.

All-new versions of C-Class cars, collectively Mercedes’s best-selling line, are being introduced for 2015. The most recent previous version was introduced in 2007. The line historically has been the automaker’s entry point, until the CLA coupe was introduced last year, with a base price of $29,900 in the 2014 model year, compared with a base price starting at $35,800 for the C-Class sedan.

Chief executives with private jets may gravitate to the E-Class, with models starting at $51,900, but Mark Aikman, department manager of digital marketing and customer relationship management at Mercedes-Benz USA, said that the C-Class was better suited to up-and-coming executives, who generally are more active on LinkedIn than those on the corporate ladder’s top rung.

“There are some captains of industry on LinkedIn, but the real power users who use LinkedIn primarily for networking are our target,” said Mr. Aikman, adding that the C-Class line was pitched to consumers from 35 to 45.
What attracted Mercedes to the contest idea is how much it mirrors the glowing endorsements users already give colleagues on the site.

“For us, especially in digital marketing, it’s important that you never really force people to do something that they’re not already doing or that they don’t already believe in,” Mr. Aikman said. With the Driven to Perform contest, he continued, “we’ve developed a program that really thrives on the ecosystem of LinkedIn and really leverages the behavior of its users.”

LinkedIn reports having 300 million members worldwide and 186 million monthly unique visitors. Among social media users, 30 percent visit LinkedIn at least once a week, fewer than those who visit Facebook (86 percent), Google Plus (43 percent) or Twitter (37 percent) that often, according to Mintel, a market research firm.

Although not the most popular, it may be the best-off major social network. LinkedIn users in the United States spend 2.51 times as much on online purchases monthly as the average Internet user, higher than users of Pinterest (1.85 times), Twitter (1.6 times) and Facebook (1.28 times), according to 2013 data from comScore.
While marketers once considered LinkedIn solely for advertising business-to-business products and services, it increasingly is drawing interest from consumer-facing brands.

In a 2013 promotion from Fruit of the Loom called “Fresh Gigs,” for example, over a five-week period the brand offered to send a free pair of underwear to LinkedIn users who had noted on their profiles that they changed jobs or gained employment.

On what’s called a Showcase Page on LinkedIn, Secret, the women’s deodorant brand from Procter & Gamble, posts about women being confident and fearless in the workplace, the implication being that it is hard to be either with substandard antiperspirant.
Mattel also recently introduced a Showcase Page on LinkedIn for “Entrepreneur Barbie,” aiming to help girls explore careers.

Penry Price, the vice president of global sales and marketing solutions at LinkedIn, said that at a site where users pursue professional objectives over social ones, they tend to be more receptive to promotional pitches.

“Mind-set matters, and when users are on LinkedIn they’re thinking about their professional identity and they’re really aspirational,” Mr. Price said. “People spend time on social networks, but they invest time on professional networks.”
Brian Morrissey, editor in chief of Digiday, an online publication that covers digital marketing and media, said Mercedes chose wisely with LinkedIn.

“Mercedes is a symbol of making it in your career, so it makes sense that they’re on LinkedIn mind-set-wise,” said Mr. Morrissey, who lauded the way the brand adapted a giveaway promotion to the site.
“They’re taking sort of a tried-and-true advertising tactic, which is the contest, and they’re contextualizing it to fit the LinkedIn environment, and I think that’s great,” Mr. Morrissey said.

The HBO-to-Looney Tunes conglomerate sits at the top of a pyramid where content is king, has no controlling shareholder and poses few insurmountable antitrust hurdles for 21st Century Fox. But winning will not just be a matter of price.

To secure his prize, Mr. Murdoch needs to be open to ditching the sort of second-class corporate governance that has, ironically, given him the audacity to attempt courageous bids like this $80 billion-plus tilt for Time Warner. Specifically, Mr. Murdoch will need to consider converting 21st Century Fox into a one-vote, one-share company to win the battle.

Time Warner has already made 21st Century Fox’s dual-class structure, which allows the Murdochs to control the company with a disproportionately small economic interest, an issue in rejecting its initial offer – and rightly so. Even with lots of help from debt markets, any 21st Century Fox bid for Time Warner will have to include a generous slug of equity.

The company’s market value is a touch under $80 billion. Say it finances around a third of the price with cash. That would still mean more than 40 percent of the combined company would be controlled by Time Warner shareholders. Add in a premium, and the share goes up.

Having grown accustomed to the democratic capitalism that has disciplined the management team led by Jeff Bewkes in recent years, Time Warner’s owners would be mad to accept stock that relegates them to the back of the Murdoch bus. Disney shareholders felt similarly in 2004 when Comcast tried and failed to buy the company with shares that guaranteed the cable company’s controlling Roberts family an unreasonable grip over the business.

And, anyway, the Murdochs need not fear the free market. If 21st Century Fox merges with Time Warner, the combined company would have an enterprise value greater than $150 billion. It would be too big for any potential interloper to swallow except, perhaps, Google, should the search giant suddenly abandon its winning strategy and its own super votes. And with the concessions a merged 21st Century Fox-Time Warner would need to make today, like selling CNN, its position would be too dominant for antitrust regulators to permit further consolidation.
Time Warner is preparing dozens of other reasonable arguments to rebuff the Murdochs. But appealing to its shareholders’ fundamental rights will need to figure most prominently.
Rob Cox is editor of Reuters Breakingviews. For more independent commentary and analysis, visit breakingviews.com.
https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/17/techn: EBay on Wednesday showed slow but steady growth in the latest quarter despite a wide-ranging security breach.

The company, which has a robust online marketplace and the payments business PayPal, reported earnings of $676 million, a 6 percent increase from the same period a year ago. “We continued our momentum in the four competitive commerce battlegrounds of mobile, local, global and data,” John Donahoe, eBay’s chief executive, said in a statement.
In May, the company’s systems were compromised by hackers, exposing the information of nearly 150 million eBay users. All eBay users were asked to reset their passwords.

Bob Swan, eBay’s chief financial officer, said on a conference call on Wednesday that the breach slowed user activity — and revenue growth — at eBay.com. Net revenue for the company’s marketplaces rose 9 percent, to $2.7 billion.

The marketplace results were also hurt by changes that Google, a competitor, made to its search engine algorithms. As a result of Google’s tinkering, some eBay pages show up less prominently in Google search results.
“While we are confident we will work through the global password reset and S.E.O. changes, it will take longer and cost more,” Mr. Swan said, referring to search engine optimization.

Mr. Donahoe was also quick to mention eBay’s joint initiative with Sotheby’s, which will bring many of the 270-year-old auction house’s live-bidding events online for eBay’s 149 million active marketplace buyers. The goal of the partnership is to create a shopping mall with Sotheby’s as its anchor tenant.

The challenges for eBay.com did not seem to slow consumers from using PayPal, the robust payments business, which had another quarter of strong growth. The company’s payments business — composed almost entirely of PayPal — was responsible for $1.9 billion in revenue, a 20 percent increase from the year-ago quarter.

Along with PayPal, eBay sees future growth tied closely to its strategy for mobile devices. Last fall, eBay purchased Braintree, an e-commerce company used by start-ups for mobile payments, and integrated the company into its PayPal division. And ultimately, eBay wants to use Braintree to bring more small and medium-size businesses into the world of online commerce.
“Many of the sharing economy companies like Uber, Airbnb and TaskRabbit use Braintree as their payments platform,” Mr. Donahoe said in an interview. “Consumers are changing their behavior.”
https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/14/techn: What goes up must come down. That principle seems to be coming true for Samsung Electronics, the world’s top cellphone maker, whose profit is falling in part because of pressure from its price-cutting rivals in China.
Samsung, a South Korean company, said last week that profit in the last quarter was expected to be 25 percent lower than in the period a year earlier.

Among other factors, Samsung blamed intense competition from Chinese manufacturers for the decline. Companies like Xiaomi and Huawei have quickly increased market share in China over the last year with the help of handsets they sell at a break-even price.

Chinese companies have swooped into many other industries, including personal computers and solar energy, to produce products less expensively. This strategy has traditionally been used after a market matures, at which point the Chinese companies find a way to make and sell products nearly at cost, building market share and eating into the profit of the incumbents.
Investors and analysts are now wondering whether Samsung will choose to cut prices or push innovation harder in order to fight back.
“How does Samsung compete against players that price at cost?” said Adnaan Ahmad, an analyst for Berenberg Bank in London, in a research note. “Investors should question where the growth is.”

Samsung’s response to its predicament could shape the entire smartphone market. If Samsung aggressively cuts prices to improve sales, it could pressure other competitors like Nokia, HTC and Motorola Mobility to lower prices, too. That could lead to lower-quality products or even slimmer margins for the smartphone business as a whole. Already, in many recent financial quarters, only Samsung and Apple have made a profit from smartphones.

The low-end market is not Samsung’s only worry. At the high end, its main rival is Apple, which has continued to improve iPhone sales. T. Michael Walkley, a Canaccord Genuity analyst, said Apple could find even more success if the company releases phones with larger screens this year, as is widely expected.

Samsung has shown no signs that it wants to go down the price-cutting path. It declined to make an executive available for an interview, but in a written statement, the company said it would continue to compete through a diverse set of products that fulfill consumer needs.
“We also will strengthen our product competitiveness by reinforcing our premium brand reputation, powerful product lineup and cutting-edge technology,” the company said.
In other words, Samsung, at least for now, plans to keep doing what it is already doing: offering a large variety of mobile products at a wide range of prices.
But it remains unclear whether that will be enough.

Ben Bajarin, a consumer technology analyst for Creative Strategies, said the competitive dynamic among devices running Google’s Android system, like most of Samsung’s and the inexpensive handsets made by Chinese manufacturers, was starting to shift.
Because all Android smartphones work similarly, he said, hardware does not make a device stand out. Software and Internet services, like video streaming or messaging, will set the devices apart.

Xiaomi, the rising Chinese electronics brand, is a chief example of that. The company makes several models of Android smartphones, including handsets that have many of the same features as top phones from Apple and Samsung, but cost less than half the price.

But the hardware and low price are just a small part of what gives Xiaomi its advantage. To lure customers and keep them loyal, the company offers a special version of Android, called Miui. Fans can help design Miui by giving feedback online, and the company releases a new version of the operating system every Friday to keep fans excited.

Xiaomi’s business model is unique among Android phone vendors. It sells phone models for about the same amount it costs to buy and assemble the materials. But it sells the phones for up to a year and a half, giving time for the components’ price to fall. Xiaomi also makes money from selling apps, games, special Android themes and Internet services.
Making money off Internet services will be Xiaomi’s core business strategy, the company has said.

“Cellphones are really just like PCs were 20 years ago,” Lin Bin, one of Xiaomi’s founders, said at a business conference last year. “They generated big profit margins in the beginning. But those margins are in the single digits now. The same thing is beginning to happen to smartphones. So rather than focus on devices where margins will decline, we’re focusing on services.”

But Samsung’s smartphone business is still reliant on selling hardware. While the company also offers specially customized versions of the Android system for its smartphones and tablets, its software has been widely panned by reviewers and customers. And in Internet services like maps and online messaging, Samsung is virtually irrelevant.

Samsung has been working with Intel and other companies on a new mobile operating system called Tizen. But Mr. Ahmad of Berenberg predicted Tizen would fail as other competing software systems have before, like Palm’s WebOS and BlackBerry’s latest software system, BlackBerry 10.
In the end, he said, the company will probably resort to cutting its prices, sacrificing profit margins even more.
“Samsung has had a knack historically of playing the price game if its market share is under any pressure,” Mr. Ahmad said. “Why should history not repeat itself for its high-end portfolio?”

Apple, too, makes most of its profit from selling hardware, but it does not share Samsung’s problems, Mr. Bajarin said. To stand out and keep customers loyal, Apple offers operating systems and Internet services that run only on Apple hardware.

A Samsung customer, by contrast, can always switch to an Android phone made by another company, log in to Google services and have basically the same phone. And if you can buy some other Android phone more cheaply than a Samsung device, why not?
“That’s really the difficult part for them,” Mr. Bajarin said. “Their customers are actually Google’s, they’re not necessarily theirs.”

I’ll admit to being a touch nervous as I opened the article delivering the results of the American National Election Study’s work on American patriotism. The millennial generation has always been one which received far more criticism, in my opinion, than was due, whether that criticism be related to work ethic, vanity, or intelligence. Here, I was pleasantly surprised to find the author, Lynn Vavreck, instead choose to focus on the positive findings rather than those which could have easily been spun to cast millennials in their popular, dim light.

The study found that while millennials were generally less moved by visual symbols of American patriotism, such as the flag, they were more concerned with philosophical aspects of the United States, e.g. equality and democracy. In contrast, older generations were found to value visual symbols more highly than those of a more intellectual matter, concerning statistics, in my opinion, for the generation currently in power to demonstrate. It is important to note that this is the same generation in power which involved the United States unnecessarily in wars, ballooned the national debt, refused to curb explosive college fees and thereby saddled millions of young people with incredible financial burden, turned a blind eye to racial and sexual discrimination, has yet to fully recognize LGBTQ community members legally or socially, allowed jobs to flee the nation, and stated that businesses are people with the same rights as, say, a young college student, pushing his/her way through school with a minimum wage job. I would argue that it is no surprise young people have turned their backs on the traditional, superficial patriotism of older generations and have become more invested in equality and democracy.

With this seeming disregard of the traditional symbols of the United States of America, perhaps the millennial generation is not as vain as they have been made out. By focusing on the more ideological aspects of American citizenship, perhaps the millennial generation has a better chance of eliminating the social blights which have clung to America for centuries than their older counterparts.

https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/12/nyreg: It certainly sounded like a joke, one of those hoaxes far too good to be true. But there was the sign, taped to a utility pole in South Slope, Brooklyn:
MISSING
Have you seen Penelope?
She’s a Mexican Red Rump Tarantula
The country has its packs of feral dogs, the suburbs have their tabbies stuck in trees, but it may take a place like New York for a missing venomous pet arachnid to arouse such interest.

The whole thing began on Thursday night when a Reddit commenter, known as laserpilot, posted a picture of the “missing” sign. “Pregnant Red Rump tarantula missing in South Slope,” the heading read. Inside was an image of Penelope, a fuzzy, palm-size creature, above a frantically apologetic appeal.

“I know she looks crazy scary,” it said, “but she’s mostly harmless. She’s pregnant, so I’m hoping to find her before she has her babies. She’s mostly active at night and likes to hide in dark corners. She shouldn’t bite, but sometimes jumps when frightened. If you find her, please try to catch her and put her in a Tupperware bowl with a few holes in the top for air. Then please call me and I will come and get her.”
So there it was: A poisonous spider with eggs in her belly and a tendency to jump was said to be on the loose in the vicinity of Fourth Avenue and 19th Street.

“If it’s real, it’s real, but I hope it’s not,” said Shanna Johnson, a postal worker whose route includes the area where the spider was said to missing. “I don’t think it’s real, but why would they lie?”

People who had seen the sign tried to determine who was behind it; Lily Burkhart, a local resident, said she had contacted several neighbors but found no one who owned a spider or knew who had posted the sign. “It’s a mystery,” she said.
Some mused that if they were to come across the tarantula, they might try to trap it under a cup. A large cup.
“I have a tendency to want to kill them, but I was taught growing up that spiders were good for nature,” said Bob Cooney, a 30-year resident of 19th Street.

Various websites suggest that a bite from a Mexican red-rump tarantula is not particularly dangerous to humans. Nonetheless, the blogosphere was ablaze on Friday with nervous worries that Penelope might give birth, and that a brood of red-rump spiders might soon take root in Prospect Park. But some knowledgeable sources said such concerns were overblown.
“I don’t think this is a harmful situation,” said Tim Wong, the technical director of M&M Pest Control, a Manhattan company with, its website says, “20 years of pest management experience.”
First of all, as Mr. Wong explained, tarantulas, like most of their spider brethren, are nocturnal. Moreover, he went on, “They don’t prey on people.”

“I think it’s kind of funny that they even put a sign up,” he added. “The odds of finding it are small at this point — very, very small. And the only time that anyone would be in danger is if they actually tried to catch it.”
Such heroism will not be necessary. By late Friday afternoon, a phone call to the number listed on the sign yielded the apparent truth: It was all a joke that had gotten out of hand.

“I always see those signs for missing dogs and cats taped up on posts; I thought, ‘What’s the most absurd poster I could come up with?’ ” the man who answered the phone said. “I thought it was so beyond ridiculous that no one would take it seriously. I was wrong.”
The man, who refused to provide his name, said he lived in the neighborhood and worked as a, er, web and graphic designer.
“I never expected it to blow up,” he said. “Then I was in the train station, looking at my Twitter feed and saw this tweet from ABC about a tarantula. I thought, ‘Oh, man.’ ”
The man said he had never owned a tarantula, or any pet for that matter. “I actually didn’t know how to spell tarantula,” he said. “I had to Google that.”

https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/15/upsho: When an unpopular president faces a difficult midterm election, candidates from his party tend to avoid him and try to focus on local issues, but the nationalization of politics has made this strategy increasingly difficult. Instead, some red-state Democrats are going out of their way to talk about President Obama more than other Senate candidates from their party — and not always in a good way.

On Wednesday, Mr. Obama visited Colorado to raise money for Senator Mark Udall’s re-election campaign, but Mr. Udall wasn’t there. Rather than travel back to the state and appear publicly with Mr. Obama, Mr. Udall stayed in Washington — ostensibly to cast a Senate vote.

As The Associated Press correctly predicted, the decision raised questions about “the political risks for vulnerable Democrats in being linked with an increasingly unpopular president.” Mr. Udall’s decision was especially striking given Obama’s record in Colorado, which he carried in the 2008 and 2012 general elections.

To examine the extent to which Democratic Senate candidates in the nine most competitive races are distancing themselves from the president, who has an approval rating in the low 40s nationally, I examined how often the candidates mentioned the president on their websites (using Google site searches last week), which is a rough measure of the emphasis being placed on Mr. Obama in campaign communications.

Mr. Udall, for instance, rarely mentions Mr. Obama on his website, where his motto states that he “puts Colorado first in Washington.” The president is mentioned even less on the website of Bruce Braley, the Democratic Senate candidate whose motto says he “works for Iowa,” another state Mr. Obama won in 2008 and 2012.

Democratic candidates in states Obama lost by significant margins mention the president more frequently, but often in the context of distancing themselves from him. Mark Pryor’s website in Arkansas notes that “Mark took on President Obama to stop cuts to Social Security,” while Mark Begich’s website in Alaska describes him as “tough on Obama” (one of his primary campaign themes). Similarly, the campaign of Alison Lundergan Grimes in Kentucky highlighted coverage of her criticism of Mr. Obama’s new E.P.A. regulation on fighting carbon pollution.

As the graph indicates, this pattern holds across the nine most competitive Senate races. Democratic candidates in states where Mr. Obama is less popular actually tend to mention him somewhat more than those in the states where he is viewed more favorably (I use 2013 approval ratings from Gallup, the most recently available state-level data.)

Whether Mr. Obama will drag his fellow Democrats down in November is an open question, but he’s clearly more of an electoral liability than an asset to his party just 20 months after being re-elected.
https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/03/techn: Facebook’s disclosure last week that it had tinkered with about 700,000 users’ news feeds as part of a psychology experiment conducted in 2012 inadvertently laid bare what too few tech firms acknowledge: that they possess vast powers to closely monitor, test and even shape our behavior, often while we’re in the dark about their capabilities.

The publication of the study, which found that showing people slightly happier messages in their feeds caused them to post happier updates, and sadder messages prompted sadder updates, ignited a torrent of outrage from people who found it creepy that Facebook would play with unsuspecting users’ emotions. Because the study was conducted in partnership with academic researchers, it also appeared to violate long-held rules protecting people from becoming test subjects without providing informed consent. Several European privacy agencies have begun examining whether the study violated local privacy laws.
But there may be other ways to look at the Facebook study and its publication. Studying how we use social media may provide important insights into some of the deepest mysteries of human behavior.

Facebook and much of the rest of the web are thriving petri dishes of social contact, and many social science researchers believe that by analyzing our behavior online, they may be able to figure out why and how ideas spread through groups, how we form our political views and what persuades us to act on them, and even why and how people fall in love.

Most web companies perform extensive experiments on users for product testing and other business purposes, but Facebook, to its credit, has been unusually forward in teaming with academics interested in researching questions that aren’t immediately pertinent to Facebook’s own business. Already, those efforts have yielded several important social science findings.

But there’s another benefit in encouraging research on Facebook: It is only by understanding the power of social media that we can begin to defend against its worst potential abuses. Facebook’s latest study proved it can influence people’s emotional states; aren’t you glad you know that? Critics who have long argued that Facebook is too powerful and that it needs to be regulated or monitored can now point to Facebook’s own study as evidence.

It is problematic that Facebook roped users into the study without their express consent. The company has apologized, and now says it will look at ways to improve its guidelines for conducting research. “After the feedback from this study, we are taking a very hard look at this process,” said Jonathan Thaw, a Facebook spokesman.
If Facebook figured out a way to be more transparent about its research, wouldn’t you rather know what Facebook can do with the mountains of information it has on all of us?

Wouldn’t you also be interested in what other tech companies know about us? How does Google’s personalized search algorithm reinforce people’s biases? How does Netflix’s design shape the kinds of TV shows we watch? How does race affect how people navigate dating sites?
After the outcry against the Facebook research, we may see fewer of these studies. That would be a shame.

“It would be kind of devastating,” said Tal Yarkoni, a psychology researcher at the University of Texas at Austin. “Until now, if you knew the right person at Facebook and asked an interesting question, a researcher could actually get collaborators at Facebook to work on these interesting problems. But Facebook doesn’t have to do that. They have a lot to lose and almost nothing to gain from publishing.”

If you’ve been cast in a Google or Facebook experiment, you’ll usually never find out. Users who are put into experimental groups are selected at random, generally without their knowledge or express permission. While Facebook says people agree to such tests when they sign up for the site, users aren’t given any extra notice when they’re included in a study.

One problem is that obtaining consent may complicate experimental results. “Facebook could throw up a bubble asking people to opt-in to each test, but it would totally mess up the results, because people would be selecting themselves into the test,” Mr. Yarkoni said. (Offline social science and medical researchers face a similar problem.) Another option would be for users to be periodically asked whether they wanted to take part in research, but some research ethicists have balked at the prospect of not giving users individual notice of each study.

Ryan Calo, an assistant professor at the University of Washington School of Law who studies technology policy, has called for companies that conduct experiments on their users to create “consumer subject review boards,” a kind of internal ombudsman who would assess each proposed experiment and balance the potential risks to users against the potential rewards.

“There’s enough pressure and understanding of this issue that these firms are going to have to come up with a way to make the public and regulators comfortable with experimenting with consumers,” Mr. Calo said.

Much of the research that Facebook and Google conduct to improve their own products is secret. Some is not. Google has acknowledged running about 20,000 experiments on its search results every year. It once tested 41 different shades of blue on its site, each color served to a different group, just to see which hue garnered the most engagement from users.

Over the last few years, Facebook has expanded what it calls its Data Science team to conduct a larger number of public studies. The company says the team’s mission is to alter our understanding of human psychology and communication by studying the world’s largest meeting place. So far, it has produced several worthy insights.

In 2012, the data team published a study that analyzed more than 250 million users; the results shot down the theory of “the filter bubble,” the long-held fear that online networks show us news that reinforces our beliefs, locking us into our own echo chambers. Like the new study on people’s emotions, that experiment also removed certain posts from people’s feeds.

In another experiment, Facebook randomly divided 61 million American users into three camps on Election Day in 2010, and showed each group a different, nonpartisan get-out-the-vote message (or no message). The results showed that certain messages significantly increased the tendency of people to vote — not just of people who used Facebook, but even their friends who didn’t.

Zeynep Tufekci, an assistant professor at the School of Information and Library Science at the University of North Carolina, points out that many of these studies serve to highlight Facebook’s awesome power over our lives.

“I read that and I said, ‘Wait, Facebook controls elections,’ ” she said. “If they can nudge all of us to vote, they could nudge some of us individually, and we know they can model whether you’re a Republican or a Democrat — and elections are decided by a couple of hundred thousand voters in a handful of states. So the kind of nudging power they have is real power.”
Ms. Tufekci has offered a stirring call to arms against Facebook, Google and other giant web concerns because of their power to shape what we do in the world. She makes a worthy argument.

But if every study showing Facebook’s power is greeted with an outcry over its power, Facebook and other sites won’t disclose any research into how they work. And isn’t it better to know their strength, and try to defend against it, than to never find out at all?
https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/07/0: The wearable computing market will be huge. Actually, it’s a passing fad. (Remember the netbook?) Or it will be a modest hit.

Forrester Research, on the other hand, thinks wearables have a short shelf life. James L. McQuivey, a Forrester analyst, said in a research report that interest in wearable devices would probably rise next year but could decline as early as 2016.

He compared the impending rise and fall of wearables to the fate of the e-book reader, MP3 player and handheld camcorder, which were all supplanted by devices like smartphones and tablets.

NPD DisplaySearch, a research firm that tracks shipments of displays, has a more complex prediction. It foresees that the wearables market will grow to 91 million devices next year, up from 48 million this year. After that, the market will cool down when consumer hype dies down.

But after that, sales could surge again, when the devices catch on in China, similar to what happened with smartphones and big-screen TVs there, says Paul Gray, director of European TV research for NPD DisplaySearch.
It’s safe to say that the jury is still out.
